citation.article-title: Rhodobacter eurynalinus sp. nov., a new halophilic purple bacterial species.

p.s: Description of Rhodobacter euryhalinus sp. nov.
Rhodobacter euryhalinus (eu.ry.ha.li.nus. Gr. adj. Eurys: wide, gr. n. hals: salt. M. L. Masc. adj. euryhalinus: wide range salinity living)
Morphology and Pigments.
The shape of cells is from coccoid to short rods, 0.7-1.0 x 1.5-3.0 μm.
The formation of straight chains, threads, and rosettes is typical.
Motile by means of a polar flagellum.
Multiplication by binary fission.
Photosynthetic membrane system of vesicular type.
The anaerobic cell suspension is from greenish-yellow to brown, the aerobic one is red.

Absorption spectra of cell syspensions in vivo show maxima at 378, 592, 805, 855 nm (bacteriochlorophyll a) and 450-460, 479-486, 509-517 nm (carotenoids of maxima at 378, 592, 802, 855 nm (bacteriochlorophyll a) and 450-460, 479-486, 509-517 nm (carotenoids of spheroidene group; position of peaks varies depending on the age of the culture and culture conditions).
Culture.

Generally photoorganoheterotrophs may also grow microaerophillically in the dark in the presence of organic substrate and photoautotrophically utilizing hydrogen, sulfide, and thiosulfate as H-donors.
Elemental sulfur, which is an intermediate product of the oxidation of H2S2 is deposited outside the cells and may be oxidized to sulfates in the absence of sulfide in the medium.
Optimal growth conditions: pH 7-8, 25-35°C.
NaCl concentration from 0.5-12% (for different strains).
Obligatorily halophilic, can develop in a wide range of salinity.
Ammonium salts can be utilized as nitrogen source.
Only 2 of 12 strains tested are capable of assimilatory sulfate reduction; type strain is not capable of it.
Sulfide, cystein, and cystine serve as sources of sulfur for all strains.
Bacteria of the majority of strains, including the type, require four vinamins; B1, B5, biotin, p-aminobenzoate.

H-donors and carbon sources: fatty acids down to caprylate (not tested further), some amino acids and intermediates of the tricarboxylic acid cycle, glycerol, glucose, gluconate, lactate, pyruvate, fructose, yeast extract, casein hydrolysate.
Malonate, mannitol, formate, ethanol are used by some strains including the type strain.
Benzoate, methanol, tartrate, and citrate are not used.
Stored nutrients: polyphosphate, poly-β-hydroxybutyrate.
Catalase activity is present.
Content of GC in DNA fluctuates from 62.1 to 68.6 mole % (seven strains; according to melting temperature), 66.3 mole % for type strain.
Habitat.
Widely distributed in shallow sea and continental salt waters with high mineralization.
Type strain KA-65 is stored in the Geochemical Activity of Microorganisms Branch, Institute of Microbiology, Academy of Sciences of the USSR, Moscow, USSR.
